supporting_quotes: Badinter graduated in law from Paris Law Faculty of the University of Paris.
He then went to the United States to continue his studies at Columbia University in New York City, where he got his MA.
He continued his studies again at the Sorbonne until 1954.
Badinter started his career in Paris in 1951, as a lawyer working with Henri Torrès.
In 1965, Badinter was appointed a professor at University of Sorbonne. He continued as an Emeritus professor until 1996.
In 1965, along with Jean-Denis Bredin, he founded the law firm Badinter, Bredin et partenaires, (now Bredin Prat) where he practised law until 1981.
In 1981, François Mitterrand, a self-professed opponent of the death penalty, was elected president and Badinter was appointed as Minister of Justice.
He remained a minister until February 1986.
From March 1986 to March 1995, he was president of the French Constitutional Council.
From 1995 to 2011, he served as a senator, representing the Hauts-de-Seine département.
Senator for Hauts-de-Seine: 1995–2011. Elected in 1995, reelected in 2004.
